intro: Psephellus gamidii, commonly known as the Armenian bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the Caucasus region. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or mountainous areas, preferring well-drained soil and full sun. It has lance-shaped leaves and produces small, tubular flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
